Subject: Imaging and Pattern Recognition

X-Yahoo-Profile: blue5432

Also, heading into the conference, Philip and I were considering
switching gears a bit.  We were planning to apply a similar "roving
eye" approach to a larger input board game with simpler strategy than
Go, such as Go-Moku.  But because of a variety of factors, including
some of what we saw at GECCO, we've decided to apply the active vision
concept to pattern recognition...we're specifically going to focus on
OCR and fingerprint recognition as application domains, although we're
architecting our active vision system to be flexible and extensible
enough to apply to any visual field, so that it could be applied to
board game domains, computer vision, x-ray analysis, satellite imaging
analysis, etc.

Ken's approach to Go showed some promise in the area of board game
play.  And Floreano's presentation included two examples of active
vision that also looked promsing, one in which a zooming, panning
"retina" scans the visual field for an autonomous driving agent in a
racetrack simulation.  The retina eventually learned to zoom in to the
white side line painted on the street and use it as a guide.  The
autonomous driver was able to outperform all the humans in Floreano's
lab.  The other example involved an active vision system for physical
robots, and in searching for papers on the subject, I found that they
also did similar experiments with an active vision system for shape
discrimination (distinguishing between triangles and squares of
different sizes on a noisy background).

Anyway, we just thought that we'd note that we're moving in this
direction, especially since there are others on the list interested in
imaging and active vision.  Hopefully we can share some useful
results/insights.  Later I'll probably post an SVG animation demo of
how we want the system to work.  We're still in the process of coding
it up, and hopefully we'll begin experiments within the next couple of
weeks.

Derek
